awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Identifying Participation Barriers to Computer Science Education in Rural Mississippi
awd_abstract_narration:
The primary goal of the small strand, K-14 project "Collaborative Research: Identifying Participation Barriers to Computer Science Education in Rural Mississippi" is to develop a researcher-practitioner partnership (RPP) to identify barriers to participation in computer science education in high poverty, rural areas of Mississippi. In the past two years, a collaborative effort between the Mississippi Department of Education (MDE) and Mississippi State University's (MSU's) Research and Curriculum Unit (RCU) implemented a statewide computer science pilot offered free of charge to K-12 schools. Entering the third year of the pilot, 74 of 148 school districts in the state are now offering computer science courses; however, it has been observed that districts situated in the most rural, highest poverty, and lowest income areas in the state (primarily the Delta region) are not participating in the opportunity to provide their teachers free computer science professional development and thereby offer students access to courses that would begin preparing them for jobs in a very high-demand, high-salary career. Through a RPP, issues and perceptions will be investigated to determine why these districts are not taking advantage of this opportunity to offer computer science education in the classrooms.

This collaborative project between MSU and Mississippi Valley State University (MVSU), a four-year institution of higher learning located in the Delta, will form a partnership with teachers, administrators, and counselors from six districts in the area surrounding MVSU, as well as the local community college, business owners, community leaders, and parents, to identify issues acting as barriers or constraints to computer science education opportunities. Identifying and addressing the root causes of the lack of participation in these types of demographic and geographic areas will give a voice to those who are most directly involved, while also transforming perceptions of computer science and broadening participation in the field based on contributions from more diverse groups, primarily African American teachers and students.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: Computer Science for All (CS for All)
EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The Collaborative Research: Identifying Participation Barriers to Computer Science Education in Rural Mississippi project had three goals within the two-year timeframe:

1. Establish a researcher-practitioner partnership (RPP),

2. Identify Delta:

barriers to computer science (CS) education,

perceptions of CS as an area of study, and

stereotypes associated with those interested in CS subjects

3. Broaden participation in CS by increasing the number of K-12 African American teachers to 20 and expose at least 400 students to CS.

The Computer Science for Mississippi (CS4MS) initiative was launched in 2016.Teacher training and continuing education units were offered at no cost and travel expenses were reimbursed. However, almost no districts in the Delta region of the state participated. This project sought to understand why this was so.

Goal 1 - Partnership: Review of year 1 revealed that a true researcher-practitioner partnership had not yet been formed. What existed was group of people who were ?voluntold? participants with little understanding of the project, its background, or expectations. The concept of working collaboratively on a research project was new to district participants.  Administrators and teachers in the Delta are accustomed to researchers coming in to provide resources or lead training but not to work in tandem with the education community to identify problems and jointly implement solutions.  This, combined with high turnover and district consolidations, made building a cohesive and consistent partnership difficult. Additionally, the Delta communities operated under an abundance of caution during the pandemic and were very restrictive about having visitors, did not encourage teachers to attend outside training or promote after-school activities for students. Even remote/online activities were discouraged due to time already missed from regular instructional time and Zoom fatigue. The turnover, combined with the shutdown and Zoom-burnout of COVID, made it difficult to schedule the time needed to develop stronger relationships. A fully functioning RPP takes a consistent team, ongoing communication, and time.

Goal 2 - Barriers: In an effort to understand perceptions of all stake-holders at the beginning of the project, student surveys and four focus groups were conducted. The findings are summarized below:

  • Teachers understand the importance of exposing students to the opportunity to take CS classes. They identified funding, teacher shortage, and emphasis on subject area testing as barriers to offering CS courses.
  • Administrators described computer scientists as nerdy white males with glasses and pocket protectors. Although they agreed that CS is important to teach early, they cited a lack of teachers and functioning equipment, the directing of resources to core courses that impact accountability points, and limited scheduling options in lower grades as deterrents. They additionally noted the lack of connection for students who do not know computer scientists that look like them and the reluctance of students to engage with CS because of the reaction of their peers who might think it is not cool to be a scientist.
  • Counselors described computer scientists similarly to the administrators and noted that computer scientists build computers from spare parts, develop robots, and code. In the counselors? experience, schools are not offering CS classes due to limited broadband, outdated equipment, a lack of funds, a teacher shortage, and the lack of emphasis on electives.
  • Parents felt that changes in administration or staff turnover and lack of resources could be impacting the offering of CS classes. They agreed that CS is important to teach to students (and parents). They felt students are held back by their lack of exposure and the stereotypes they hold about CS. Some kids get overlooked as not being college material when their interest might be sparked by CS.
  • Student survey respondents were 142 in 2019 and 120 in 2022. Questions included student beliefs around what type of activities are considered CS, perceptions of CS and CS professionals, and interest and confidence in learning CS. While overall perceptions and learning did not shift dramatically between 2019 and 2022, student beliefs about CS changed from designing and building websites in 2019 to programming and coding in 2022. This, along with the frustration many experienced with online learning during COVID, may explain why student interest and confidence was significantly lower in 2022 (t(p)=-3.23(<.001)).

Goal 3 - Broadening Participation: Four of the five districts have over 92% African American enrollment (The fifth is at 57%). In 2017 no CS courses were being offered, no trained teachers available, and no students enrolled in any of the participating schools. At the project?s close, 33 teachers had been trained (19 received a middle or high school endorsement) and 3,997 students were enrolled in a CS course.

While there is work to be done to form stable partnerships, the project did accomplish the important goals of increasing CS teacher preparedness and student exposure as well as understanding what barriers must be overcome in order to achieve more CS growth Delta schools.


Last Modified: 01/24/2023
Modified by: Shelly R Hollis

por.por_txt_cntn:
The Collaborative Research: Identifying Participation Barriers to Computer Science Education in Rural Mississippi project had three goals within the two-year timeframe:

1. Establish a researcher-practitioner partnership (RPP),

2. Identify Delta:
barriers to computer science (CS) education,

stereotypes associated with those interested in CS subjects

3. Broaden participation in CS by increasing the number of K-12 African American teachers to 20 and expose at least 400 students to CS.

The Computer Science for Mississippi (CS4MS) initiative was launched in 2016.Teacher training and continuing education units were offered at no cost and travel expenses were reimbursed. However, almost no districts in the Delta region of the state participated. This project sought to understand why this was so.

Goal 1 - Partnership: Review of year 1 revealed that a true researcher-practitioner partnership had not yet been formed. What existed was group of people who were ?voluntold? participants with little understanding of the project, its background, or expectations. The concept of working collaboratively on a research project was new to district participants.  Administrators and teachers in the Delta are accustomed to researchers coming in to provide resources or lead training but not to work in tandem with the education community to identify problems and jointly implement solutions.  This, combined with high turnover and district consolidations, made building a cohesive and consistent partnership difficult. A fully functioning RPP takes a consistent team, ongoing communication, and time.

Goal 2 - Barriers: In an effort to understand perceptions of all stake-holders at the beginning of the project, student surveys and four focus groups were conducted. The findings are summarized below:

Teachers understand the importance of exposing students to the opportunity to take CS classes. They identified funding, teacher shortage, and emphasis on subject area testing as barriers to offering CS courses.
Administrators described computer scientists as nerdy white males with glasses and pocket protectors. Although they agreed that CS is important to teach early, they cited a lack of teachers and functioning equipment, the directing of resources to core courses that impact accountability points, and limited scheduling options in lower grades as deterrents. They additionally noted the lack of connection for students who do not know computer scientists that look like them and the reluctance of students to engage with CS because of the reaction of their peers who might think it is not cool to be a scientist.
Counselors described computer scientists similarly to the administrators and noted that computer scientists build computers from spare parts, develop robots, and code. They felt students are held back by their lack of exposure and the stereotypes they hold about CS. Some kids get overlooked as not being college material when their interest might be sparked by CS. 
Student survey respondents were 142 in 2019 and 120 in 2022. Questions included student beliefs around what type of activities are considered CS, perceptions of CS and CS professionals, and interest and confidence in learning CS. This, along with the frustration many experienced with online learning during COVID, may explain why student interest and confidence was significantly lower in 2022 (t(p)=-3.23(<.001)).


Goal 3 - Broadening Participation: Four of the five districts have over 92% African American enrollment (The fifth is at 57%). In 2017 no CS courses were being offered, no trained teachers available, and no students enrolled in any of the participating schools. At the project?s close, 33 teachers had been trained (19 received a middle or high school endorsement) and 3,997 students were enrolled in a CS course.

While there is work to be done to form stable partnerships, the project did accomplish the important goals of increasing CS teacher preparedness and student exposure as well as understanding what barriers must be overcome in order to achieve more CS growth Delta schools.
